So we have Estonian Genome Foundation, created at the same time as, more or less -- as the digital Estonia, and it's very similar in -- in what we did in digital. We probably have done other things, but they have not flied (ph). This flied (ph).

It flied (ph) for short term, from 2000 to 2003, because, you know, we created this environment where population and genetics was legal, and it wasn't in most countries, globally. It was in Iceland. Iceland was our only competitor, but, luckily, they have even tinier population. So, to do population genetics in a population of 300,000 is -- is more of a joke than doing it in 1.3 million, which is still a joke, but something.

(LAUGHTER)

So private companies flocked in and paid for founding Estonia Genome Foundation. It was done on investment banking finance only. But then what happened? The governments came in. The other governments, entering (ph) the market, because they, of course, started to buy all these services, because, of course, companies were clever enough to say that you have to pay. It's not enough to create legal space.

And then, for 10 years, it was dormant until the technology became so cheap that, now, we can continue with -- with helping our people to understand the genetic risks of having heart attack, or diabetes II and other of these common ailments.

But, again, very often, people ask, then, that "Are you afraid of" -- and we say no, because we know that this data is protected. The state knows how to protect data. And -- and it's in -- it's still in my ownership.

I mean, yes, it is in some kind of a database, but I own it. It's not state's. It's mine, and I decide who uses it, and how. Personally, I don't mind if you know that my diabetes II risk is higher, and it is. But that's fine with me, so I can tell it openly.

And I think it's important we work on these areas, as well, because 90 percent of the world's population, when they feel sick, what do they do first? Google. Nowadays, what you have on Google is mostly rubbish medical information.

But you need to have solid alternatives for people. So medical doctors need to have access to people's data -- of course, without names and everything, so -- to analyze and create self-learning medical doctors who are able to respond to people.

NHS in Great Britain is experimenting, actually, that, if people call in the emergency line, and it's established that, in fact, it's not an emergency, then they are trying, with -- with a robot, to try to, well, direct this person to go to pharmacy or to go to doctor or whichever way.

But these systems have to have databases to learn. And donating your information to them -- health information or genetic information -- in an anonymous format is a great thing to do for humanity. But it needs to be safe, and it can be safe.

SCIUTTO: But -- but how could you -- I guess the issue is, even with regulation, the question becomes confidence, right, and confidence in security, because I'm someone -- and listen, I -- I have such a baseline level of -- of digital knowledge, but -- but I have an assumption -- and this is partly because of the work that I do, but I -- also, I lived in China -- I have assumption that there is no actual privacy, because I've been a victim of -- of three or four -- of the three or four biggest hacks: the OPM hack, the Anthem Healthcare one, and I forget what the other one -- I've lost track.

I have so many free digital ID services paid for by various entities that mishandled my information, I -- I don't even know. So how do you get those two to come together? Because you could have that knowledge, but, without confidence, then, you know...

KALJULAID: First thing first. This is the big problem of developing digital country like Estonia: Lots of digital services provided online, indeed, with identification ways -- I don't know. You use some username and some code, and then you write it on your computer, have a special file in your computer, et cetera. It's unsafe, terribly unsafe.

Or take a very -- it's a concrete example. I got it from Rudy Giuliani -- or I put the example together, but I learned from him. E-prescription's pretty popular in United States, but it's an e-mail. I'm sorry.

And, when something goes wrong with this e-mail, e-prescription, then confidence in all e-prescriptions is down the drain, including ours. But our e-prescription system is much safer. You -- you can never say it's absolutely safe, but it's definitely safer than paper analogs (ph), so I'm quite sure I call it safe.

But, when something goes wrong in one service, people lose trust in others. And that is where we need to go up (ph) the confidence and trust of all our people, constantly explaining to our people where we differ.

KALJULAID: We are not, I mean, holding this to (ph) ourselves. Actually, we very much like to expand our -- our X-Road, what we call, which is our identification system.

Finland is using the same, and we can change real -- real-time data with them. We don't, because we haven't sold it legally, but, technically, we already can, if -- for example.

So we are open to others to use ours or similar systems. We are not telling that you cannot do it. But, if you come with us into this world, you have to take responsibility to -- explaining to your people how these services work.

And, in addition, you have to promise that you make some promises to your people about how -- and then you have to apply this in your law base (ph) -- how you use this data, how you protect this data, what is your obligation vis-a-vis your people in case you have this data.

For example, I would absolutely refuse to distribute our X-Road's technology to a company for -- which I knew that it has, let's say, only one single database where it tends to gather all the information about its citizens, et cetera.

But, I mean, if you do it in a smart -- smart and sharp way, and protect this, also, legally, what you are doing, and protect your people, it can be done, not only in Estonia, but all that's following (ph). Denmark is quite good example, Luxembourg is quite good example. We are small, but it's something.

SCIUTTO: Before -- I do want to go to the audience soon -- I do want to ask you about blockchain, because I know this is at the top of your list of interests.

Is the -- and, just out of curiosity, and you know far more than me -- but the bursting of the Bitcoin bubble, or at least the volatility there -- is that a just a bump on the road towards all the potential of blockchain technology?

KALJULAID: Well, do we want to talk blockchain or Bitcoin? Let's agree on that first?

(LAUGHTER)

SCIUTTO: It's an example.

KALJULAID: Totally bad example. Let's take, then, Bitcoin.

(LAUGHTER)

And, for Bitcoin, you don't need to be a -- a well -- well-established macroeconomists to understand that money needs economy, and a link to a real economy. Then you know whether you have too much money, too little money, is it overvalued, undervalued -- all this.

I ask you, where's the underlying economy of Bitcoin? There isn't. Or, if there is, then we cannot measure it; therefore, we cannot understand what's the value of Bitcoin. This much about Bitcoin -- I mean, this is an illusion.

This has an interesting afterthought, if I think more about the Bitcoin situation. A well-known A.I. example says that A.I. is dangerous because it will make the world into paper clips. And then people say, "No, no. A.I. will not be so stupid as to make the world into paper clips."

And I've also thought that maybe it wouldn't. But, now, I mean, we are not A.I. We are human beings, and we mine Bitcoin. We spend real-life resources to the detriment of our environment -- lots of energy, et cetera, and other resources -- to mine something which has absolutely no value. So, I mean, where exactly are we better than A.I., here, in this problem?

Now, to blockchain, this is different thing. Blockchain is a technology which allows different systems to keep track about what different systems around it, with which it is connected, are doing. And we think this is very useful technology.

It's -- it's one step forward from what we have, because our digital signature, for a normal person, would look pretty much like blockchain, because it's signature and it's timestamped. It's similar enough for experts to look for the authors (ph) of Bitcoin in Estonia, but it's not the same technology.

So blockchain allows -- for our case, we think it will allow our state to go proactive in offering services. How? Right now, we still have to apply for state digital services, one by one. For example, you have a child. You register the birth, then you apply for social services.

But our people are starting to ask this question that -- I mean (ph), "Government, you promised you would only ask once. Now, you have the information that I have a baby, and we are entitled to a certain payment for this baby."

It's not relevant how much you earn, we have universal child support in Estonia. "So why on earth, government, you now force me to apply, even if I can do it online? Why I need to go to some home page and, I mean, ask for this service? You can simply provide it to me. I have a baby. You know my bank account, because it's -- I pay taxes. And you know I'm entitled to this money. So why should I ask?"

And the answer is, because we don't have blockchain. Our systems do not have the capacity to make sure that -- I mean, one system -- what one system is doing -- that something's not going wrong at the same time at -- in the different system. Blockchain will help us to solve this problem.

Our pilot is not social -- social security, because this is a high-confidence-level-demanding service. Our pilot there is traffic accident -- simple traffic accident, which happens every day. I mean, two cars get a little bit ruined. It's an insurance case. And we think that we -- by using blockchain, we can solve it in 30 minutes -- all the administrative questions.

So you register your traffic accident. We have, of course, online car registry, and all these elements are there -- online insurance, full database of insurance schemes, et cetera. So we could, actually, in 30 minutes, we think, send information to both parts (ph) of the accident, and -- about how this incident was solved.

But, for this, we need to have blockchain, which makes us also to think that -- when is the point when we need to create a legal entity for an -- learning -- or a machine learning system, or a machine system? And we feel we are coming quite close to this point. So we are now discussing exactly with -- how to regulate -- how to regulate, well, autonomous systems in our law base.

Attribution questions will rise. And then, of course, it will be an interesting question. I think I read it this morning in one Estonian daily (ph) -- it -- lawyers were discussing that, if a robot kills somebody, then how do we know that the robot did not get the order from its owner to kill somebody, but simply went crazy?

And, I mean, it's -- it's not -- I mean, it's not a laughing matter. This is the questions we need to solve. And also, for our -- this proactive state, we need to solve this question, and, yet again, we need to solve the question of privacy.

People probably need to somehow opt in to this kind of system, understanding and analyzing, themselves, whether they want to use or they don't want to use this.

So it's not easy, but we are thinking forward and we are forced to think forward, because, exactly, people are asking, "You know this. Why do I need to apply at all?" It's people who want this.

And government, once it has undertaken this digital disruption of society, cannot back off. You have to continuously, all the time, first of all, make sure that the existing systems are still safe to use, that you can patch them up if something goes wrong and that you can continue developing.

And it is also true that, sometimes, things go wrong. We have at least two means of identification online. Yesterday, for two hours, one of them was down. The other was working. So we need to have alternatives. But the problem with our country is that you cannot have digital with paper alternative. You have to have digital with digital alternative.

And -- and we had this problem last year, where there is a chip maker, whom I wouldn't name, but maybe some of you know, which actually called 1 billion chips off the market, said that they aren't safe to use.

Most of these were door cards (ph). High number was actually ID cards, but mostly in the countries which -- where people have IDs, but don't use them. So they could be simply, well, shut down for a while.

We couldn't do it. For us, it was right that (ph) the service continues, because our people refused it otherwise. They wouldn't go to offices to queue for services.

KALJULAID: They even got really angry that -- because some of them finally -- most of them could solve the problem online, but some couldn't. And they had to go to a police or border guard office. And then, we got loads of complaints that -- oh, kidding (ph), I had to queue for an hour. And I mean, and then you explain to people that people in Western Europe normally take a day off to register their car.

So this is where you have your population, and this also demonstrates to you that whatever Estonian government wants you to do -- go completely back to paper-based system for example -- it simply cannot. Disruption has happened, and now you have to live with the consequences and work forward to make sure that you are actually -- well, continuing to provide services to your people, to their satisfaction.

Which means that even we are on the Mars already, our people want us to be even further. I mean so, Earth for them is not the solution.

SCIUTTO: So wait, should we buy up block chain, or -- I wasn't clear. I'm joking.

(LAUGHTER)

I got the answer loud and clear. OK, so we're going to go to the -- to the assembled audience here for questions. I think we have about a half hour. Gentleman in the back with his hand raised? And there are -- yes, there are microphones.

Please if you can, identify yourself. And the other guidance I always give is phrase it in a question rather than a statement or a speech.

(LAUGHTER)

QUESTION: Michael Shraig (ph) with MIT.

Estonia is a very small country, as you pointed out. China, huge country. United States, huge country. Key to making machine learning work is scale. You're a small -- you're a scientist, you're from a small country, but you deal with giants and behemoths.

What's the most important thing you've learned about managing scale in an environment where petabytes and zettabytes is the future of what you're talking about?

KALJULAID: First thing to realize is indeed that scale wise, we don't create technology. We use technology quite common in private sector globally, so we don't have to carry the cost, and we fully understand that we don't control the delivery chain of this technology.

And this is why we need to make sure we're using, let's say, these digital chips, that we also have mobile I.D., for example, because we simply don't control the technology. But this is what makes it available.

If you now look more locally in Estonia, then since we've had absolute inclusivity, this digital chip is part of our I.D. card, with which we travel as well, at least within the European Union. Then this inclusivity from the other side is (inaudible). So for local services actually, companies have it quite good. They have the 1.3 million market at least, immediately at their hand.

SCIUTTO: Gentleman here?

QUESTION: I thank you for your comments today. Two questions, one -- are (ph) there related. One is recently Estonia joined a number of other countries, including the U.S., in condemning the NotPetya worm and attributing it to Russia.

This is always a delicate question when you have this kind of collective response. What -- attribution the other day is a -- is a, you know, political issue. What level of confidence do you need, does Estonia need, to join that kind of collective because it's more powerful?

And then on Russia, what kinds of actions would you think would be effective in actually deterring their behavior in cyberspace? You said that we need to do more. McMaster said that last night. What kinds of things would actually work?

KALJULAID: In cyberspace, we need monitoring, and we need to agree that international monitoring is allowed, and that there will be elements and events which will trigger international monitoring, very similarly as you have with (ph) sensitive nuclear technology globally. We need to agree what it is.

I give you a few examples. Radical shift in energy consumption in some laboratory or somewhere is one thing. Second is now we understood that we need to create the, like, neural networks to be able to think of A.I. which will not consume so much energy that it will be dead immediately. These could be regulated. This is hardware after all. This could be regulated that you need to allow international monitoring, and this -- well, we need to bring in globally all countries. Because as I said, it's not anymore enough like in the nuclear case, that some countries agree and the rest will simply, well, accept because they don't have the weapons. It's global, and we don't know where it will -- where it will happen. So this much for regulation.

For confidence level, it's not quantitative; it's always qualitative analysis, and depends -- well it very much, you have to go case by case.

But it's interesting that we're joining (ph), because for us it's a solidarity act, because NotPetya didn't pass in Estonia, only in one international company system, which was not linked to Estonian system. Pure (ph) act of solidarity.

QUESTION: Is there a mic?

SCIUTTO: Yeah, it's coming.

QUESTION: Fran Burwell from the Atlantic Council.

Two questions. First off, when you are thinking about how to deter or respond to an attack, does it matter if it is a nation-state behind it, or whether it is organized crime, or is it the same response?

KALJULAID: Same.

QUESTION: And -- OK. And the other thing is, you raised the issue of taxes. But your approach to tax sounds a little bit different for me from what has been proposed by some E.U. governments, including in terms of taxing digital enterprises, which, as you're well aware, some people here fear is aimed primarily at some large U.S. companies in Europe. Can you be a little bit more specific about where you think taxes should go to counter this -- to deal with this new world?

KALJULAID: I can be a little bit more specific. Fully aware that first of all, I am in -- I'm in contradiction with much of the European thinking, plus OSCE (ph) rules, everything. So we absolutely need to modify international space, and we cannot go alone. So we need to first understand that, I mean, we have this problem, and then we need to start seeking solutions. And voluntary declaration of (inaudible) with any chosen state would be actually something, which probably is the -- is the solution to the problem. And I realize I'm -- that we are very far from -- from getting there.

Meanwhile, Europe is doing what they always do in these kinds of systems. You apply a patch, and then you see what you can do to solve -- solve the problem as it is. And I think applying patches meanwhile to make sure that society is at least accepting that, I mean, we do need to tax differently, just because internet exists, is -- is a step in right direction. Of course it can be inhibitive to -- to some investment and so on. And I'm not necessarily supporting it, but I see where it comes from politically.

SCIUTTO: Gentleman standing in the back?

QUESTION: I'm Basil Scarliss (ph). I've been involved in foreign affairs.

And I have a question on sanctions. Perhaps a good way to deter Russian cyber attacks and other meddling and military action would be to have a more effective regime for punishing the Russian leader and the oligarchs.

And one obstacle is that in the United States, and to some extent in the United Kingdom, we allow shell companies to purchase properties, to make investments in corporations and in other organizations without revealing the beneficial owner; they can hide behind an attorney.

The question I have, is do you think it would be much more effective to have targeted sanctions, especially if we could get Congress to pass appropriate legislation?

KALJULAID: Simple answer would be yes.

Then the political answer would be doesn't concern me, because Estonia doesn't have that much oligarchic money in the country. It's a tiny economy, completely transparent as well, because digital makes it also transparent.

And -- and the practical answer is that I think yes, but we must make sure that we remain rule-of-law countries while we do it, as well. This is very important.

SCIUTTO: If I could follow on that, this issue comes up -- it came with the response to Skripal attack -- that the next level would have been true financial penalties for people in power.

You'll often hear -- whether with Ukraine, U.S. election interference -- about going after Putin's money, whether freezing it or exposing it to -- to his people -- all of his various holdings around the world.

Why hasn't that happened yet, in your view?

KALJULAID: I simply don't know.

SCIUTTO: Good answer.

There's a group of folks here, but maybe I'll just go from the forward, back. There's a gentleman, and then behind two, and we'll go from there.

QUESTION: Hans Binnendijk from SAIS. First of all, let me say it's so refreshing to hear a president be able to converse the way you do on these issues.

I'd like to ask about Russian attacks using social media. This is below the denial-of-service level. What has been your experience -- not just in Estonia, but in a -- in the Baltic States in general -- with regard to Russian use of social media to try to affect the opinions of your minorities -- Russian-speaking minorities?

What have you been able to do about that? I presume you're countering it. And what lessons do you have for us in this area?

KALJULAID: First, Baltic states -- well, I cannot say we have seen more of these kind of attacks. I think Germany has had a fair share, and visa case (ph) -- every German knows it. And -- and Emmanuel Macron called Putin out on disrupting the French election processes.

We have been expecting and preparing for -- when EFP (ph) was established -- that we will have quite some. Lithuania had one, but the reaction was so quick -- retaliation from Lithuania -- to inform people that this is false news, to make sure that everybody got it -- it was false news -- was so good.

But we've actually not seen any further elements. But we are, of course, ready all the time. And the only way to be ready is to tell your people this exists. We talk about troll factories. We show people that they do exist. And, frankly, try to read anonymous internet commentary under some article about -- I don't know, I do it under my articles about myself.

I recognize a troll writing quite soon. They are trying to put a message out about you, which comes whichever way -- I mean, it -- it comes. And you have a few -- few kind of names which always will appear. And then you learn to recognize it.

And -- and people, having live in -- lived a long time in the internet sphere, learn to understand this. Of course, we all have a big problem that most of the population is not able to differentiate between journalism -- something which pretends to be journalism and -- and something which think it is journalism, because they are -- well, I think those people who don't realize that they are not journalists, but they do -- don't do it in bad will.

And, previously, I expected journalists to check their facts when they provide them to me. For some reason, I cannot do it, and I think here is also a frank discussion to be had, because lots of fakes new -- fake news will die if people knew that the safe channels will never pick them up. Yet safe channels stay after they (ph) pick them up.

And we need to radically think how to avoid this. First of all, we all need to start paying for our online news, and then we can continue this discussion. I'm sorry it starts with that. Currently, the media sector has no resources to deal with it.

SCIUTTO: There's a couple questions coming in from Twitters (ph). So, Madam President, this one is, "We have an obligation to explain the issues around privacy and responsibility to citizens," relevant to what you were just discussing. "How has Estonia brought citizenry to a level where they can understand the explanation?"

And I'm -- I could identify with this, because, I'm sure, like you, you agree to terms that you don't know or read what those terms are, frequently. And so how do you manage that?

KALJULAID: We have only one set of terms, and this is state-guaranteed digital identity. It's not too much to ask people to understand one set of terms and conditions.

And the terms and conditions are roughly the same. You keep your identity -- physical one -- separate from the passwords. And, if this, for some reason, was not the case, you run quickly or go online quickly somewhere where you can, well, just close your identity.

This is the basic drill. But we have to do it only one copy, because we have the universal system. And that is how we can build trust. And, of course, it is -- government is on the line.

It's government which is giving this currently. It's not Google or Amazon or -- or somebody anonymous or not in your country. And I'm sorry -- it wouldn't get better unless more governments take this responsibility.

SCIUTTO: (Inaudible) gentleman in the beard, and then -- well, actually, you both have beards. So...

(LAUGHTER)

... we'll just have to go to -- left to right.

QUESTION: Hey. Matt Leonard with Government Computer News.

Can you talk briefly about the data embassy that you guys opened up last summer, what its current role is and any plans for opening up other data embassies, going forward?

KALJULAID: There's not much to talk about. It's a simple thing. Every private enterprise has a safe copy of everything it has, and, if the country's legal base allows it, has it outside of the country.

Now, we have a copy of Estonian state, every minute, every moment, in -- in a data embassy. And, since it is state and state data and we need to make sure that our law base about this data and what applies to this data will apply to where it is, we cannot simply establish a server somewhere.

We need to have an agreement with Luxembourg, also a very digitally minded and forward-looking country, that we will create a data embassy. So this server park (ph) is a sovereign territory of Estonia, and these servers and this data is -- belong to Estonian state. And, again, there is nothing technologically interesting.

Interesting thing is law space, which we two together created, between Luxembourg and Estonia. Whether we need to have more copies -- well, time will tell. But I am quite sure that people would -- would be quite happy to host Estonian data embassy.

On the other hand, other states need data embassies too. So -- they all have data which they need to store.

SCIUTTO: And just -- I'm curious. Are those updated constantly, then? Because, if my -- my -- if I'm an insurance company, I don't know -- today's data is different from next week's data?

KALJULAID: Yes. As I said, all Estonian digital signatures are timestamped. So, in this sense, they are like blockchain, yes.

SCIUTTO: And then did you (ph) -- if you still have a question -- the gentleman here.

QUESTION: Thank you very much. Grigory (ph) (inaudible) of Russian news agency. So, first question, how -- do you think Estonia needs more NATO (ph) troops to deter Russia? And, if so, how many troops do you need?

And the second one is about Skripal poisoning. So Estonia expelled a Russian diplomat, and -- but British experts said yesterday that they don't know a region of the agent that poisoned Skripal and his daughter.

So do you -- do you still believe your actions to expel Russian diplomat was justified? And do we (ph) have any evidence of Russian involvement in these poisoning? Or this is just a matter of solidarity with European countries?

KALJULAID: As most countries trace (ph) -- they didn't send out simply diplomats. They sent out diplomats who were acting in a way as diplomats shouldn't act. So there was another reason for -- for this concerted action.

What -- what concerns NATO troops, then -- NATO deterrence is -- well, has a history of being 100 percent efficient and effective. NATO has never failed to protect its territory. And it's -- in its entirety.

And we trust into this capacity to deter. And we're quite sure that all NATO steps are always adequate to make sure that this deterrence is -- is -- is valued.

In the summer, NATO summit will come together and discuss again those issues and these -- those elements. Our role there is to provide honest and open analysis of the security situation, considering conventional risks around our territory and among those -- well, is the information, which we have also talked publicly.

Today, the level of conventional capacity surrounding NATO's eastern flank is at the level of 2009 Zapad exercise. We need to draw conclusions from that.

SCIUTTO: In the far back here.

QUESTION: Hi.

So, I've read that there are efforts to use blockchain technology in order to -- for example, in the Estonian stock exchange, to make voting easier and more secure and like it -- you know, immutable ledger and all that. You know, it's distributed.

There's also efforts in Australia to -- company called My Vote, I think, to utilize the -- you know, relatively secure and distributed immutable ledger to help voting. And I've also heard the idea for voter registries.

So I'm just curious, is Estonia considering using blockchain for voter database -- or yeah, voter registry databases, or e-voting -- like direct e-voting itself for candidates, or for referendums at the local level or at the larger level?

Because I've heard that. It's an interesting idea and Estonia seems to be a little bit on the cutting edge of using those technologies.

So yeah, just blockchain in voting systems basically is the question.

KALJULAID: Basically, we have e-voting and this system is tried and tested and free for everybody to try and hack. And voting is the highest confidence level digital service, so you change our voting technology only when you have tried and tested the new technology developments. And you have taught your people that this technology is safe.

On lower confidence level of services, voting should be the last which will shift technology, once you already have an established system of secure voting, which we have.

So I predict that all other Estonian public services will be blockchain based before our e-voting system will change.

And I always tell to other countries, some -- some countries would say, "Let's start from e-voting." And I always say, "That's a terribly bad idea. Start from school applications or something really -- well, low-worry services. Never start from e-voting."

You have to teach a population cyber hygiene first. You have to teach them to trust the system. And only then you should apply -- you should try to apply this technology to high-confidence level services like voting.

On the other hand, sometimes we get discussion that e-voting must be terribly unsafe. And it comes from people who vote by post, so beats me how this discussion can come up, but it does still come up.

SCIUTTO: Well, it's a very common fear here, though. I think you would -- I can't imagine a -- and, of course, it's run by states here, but I can't imagine a state legislature who'd push hard for it today, because there is that lack of confidence.

Question from Twitter here: "Madam President, you speak about the need for government-mandated digital identity. Many people are concerned that this gives too much power to governments. Do you see a need for anonymous transactions? And if so, in what cases?"

KALJULAID: Well, I'm -- in my character, I'm a simple housewifish politician, and -- and this philosophical question has been bothering me a long time now. Why people in free world trust their banks and Google and Amazon, but don't trust their government?

And I don't -- I don't know the answer, but I think we need to have some really good philosophers and social scientists analyzing this question.

It's not technology what they are mistrusting. They are not trusting, for some reason, their government. I don't know why.

It may be different in every society. There may be similarities. I come from a society where people trust government in this sense. They don't trust it for, I don't know, having -- having a good tax system, or actually our people are very, very critical about our -- our government. It's a national tradition to think we are a badly run country.

(LAUGHTER)

I'm not joking. I mean, in 1943, the chairman of the Bank of England, Lord Wedgwood, he said that Estonia was the best-run country in northern Europe. And then one of our politicians said that the other diplomats told him that, and it's astonishing how little your people appreciate it.

(LAUGHTER)

It's still the same.

But they trust government when government provides digital services.

SCIUTTO: There's a gentleman here along the aisle, and then we'll go to the back. I think we're getting down to probably the last question or two.

QUESTION: All right, thank you. Johnathan Lynchman (ph) from the Providence Group.

You've mentioned a couple of times about educating the public, cyber hygiene. And I was wondering if you could tell us a little bit about what Estonia does with respect to public education on cyber-security and public information, in terms of making sure that it's both effective and that it reaches everyone.

KALJULAID: Well, teaching hygiene is not as effective as, I don't know, applying some social services. It never will be, because if you think about when we taught people simple hygiene, it was also a lengthy process which gradually reached our people's brains. That you have to wash hands, otherwise you will fall sick; or you have to use toilets, because it's not hygienic to just go to the wood.

And it took us time. But I think we have nowadays much better communication means to teach our people cyber hygiene.

And the truth is, we have to start from this and many people haven't done it. Technology will not solve it. There will never be a technology which will be able to cover for all human errors. The only way is to tell people that, "You are responsible."

And the way to do it is education. I mean, you have to teach people at school about the risks of internet. We have (inaudible) police which goes around the schools and teaches children. And it also teaches them that it's just -- I mean, if it's not nice to be rude toward, well, the other kids in class in real life, it's as rude in internet, et cetera. It starts from this low-level thing.

On the other hand, I recognize that most countries are now in bigger difficulty than Estonia, because we started teaching cyber hygiene at the turn of the century. And then the risk was some virus, and you just downloaded Kaspersky or something else. And -- and then it was cleared. Now you have to jump into the internet of things.

Yet saying that it's impossible doesn't -- I mean, doesn't solve the problem, so we have to try. And I think it has to go down to (inaudible) and primary education, this cyber hygiene teaching.

SCIUTTO: Oh, right here in the front. And then we'll go to the back, if that's OK. Sorry, I'm having you...

QUESTION: I can -- I -- I'm pretty loud. I'm Claudia Jona (ph) from the Atlantic Council.

What is your take on the -- on the -- (inaudible) deadlock (ph) on the global discussion on cyber norms? What is your take on -- on why the discussion -- where it's where it is right now?

KALJULAID: I'm disappointed that the process in United Nations fell through. And I'm quite sure that we need to revive it.

Estonia, among other things, have decided to run for United Nations Security Council, and we are in the active phase of campaign. And whether we win or we lose, this is in our talking points about discussing global security.

New Zealand took climate to the Security Council. We will take digital to the Security Council. And when we are elected, and we hope we will be, this is (inaudible) platform, definitely, and we need to continue.

There was a working group. Marina Coleron (ph) from Estonia was -- was -- was responsible for that work as well, and -- and we were deeply disappointed when this got stalled. But the problem has not gone away.

SCIUTTO: In the back, here.

QUESTION: Madam President, Franica Jerka (ph), Broadcasting Board of Governors.

In this city, there is ongoing discussion how to counter Russian propaganda (inaudible). So my question is, do you believe the blocking of Russian TV channels, like it was made in Ukraine, like it will -- it will be in Moldova, in other countries, is an efficient measure? And the second question, do you think is it a good time for now, especially now, for Western countries -- United States, European Union -- to create, re-create, revive (inaudible) broadcasters like Voice of America or PRL (ph) in Baltic states or central European countries? Thank you.

KALJULAID: I don't believe in restricting access to media outlets, even if I don't think they are free media outlets. I believe in telling my people that these are not free media outlets, so this is something which pretends to be media, or it's a government-run media. And we in Estonia, we do not restrict access to these media, yet we discuss this -- these channels and -- and everybody's free to choose whether, for example, to talk to them, and to -- how to react to them. But it needs to be known, and this is important.

But we need to not only think in the terms of Russia here. I think it would help everybody in this discussion to realize that the sources of fake news are numerous actually. I mean, I'm -- I'm pretty tough on Russia, but, I mean, sometimes I feel that people attribute all the problems in the global world to Russia.

Fake news can come from everywhere. There are various reasons for producing fake news, including somebody may simply want to sell their products, and -- and do away with somebody else's. I don't know. Somebody could say that Asics -- Asics running gear is -- is dangerous to your legs, and that doctors have analyzed and realized that because the first and -- and the back kind of padding are separate -- which is not the case for Nike running shoes -- it's dangerous.

So I mean, we have to analyze this in general, and need to teach our people how to check the facts. On the other hand, again, we need to get back a media space which we can trust somehow.

SCIUTTO: I think this -- well, let's see. Maybe we have time for two more up there quick. There's a lady here, and then someone who I keep forgetting to go to in the way, way back.

QUESTION: Thank you very much. Susan Ness, SAIS Center for Transatlantic Relations.

We talked extensively about the fake news issue. Also, within the European Union, there are efforts underway with respect to hate speech, to curtail that through government regulation. We'd like to know whether there is a major hate speech problem within Estonia, and if so, what role should government play in curtailing hate speech? Thank you.

KALJULAID: First of all, I don't sense that we have a big hate speech problem in Estonia. Second, I think that good habits is something which you shouldn't always try to write into the law text, because if we do away with good habits, and only go by law, then we are not the humankind. We like it, and we want it. So I don't believe in regulating everything.

I think most people can recognize when it is hate speech. When -- when it goes to the territory that considerable losses are occurred (ph) to the other party by -- by something which has been said, then we have our court system, which can provide and solve (ph), even in the current legal space, for these cases. But I don't think that, well, you should legislate something you cannot define, really.

SCIUTTO: So this will have to be the final one. And I can only see your hand, so I can't say -- oh, there you are.

QUESTION: Hi. How do you -- I mean, in terms of the ever-evolving capabilities of A.I., how long until you think machines will supplant the human workforce? And what will the workforce do with their newfound time? And I guess that's the end of my question.

(LAUGHTER)

KALJULAID: I am a politician; I'm not clairvoyant. But first of all, we see already that technology does not only take away jobs, but it creates it as well. I gave you a few examples, how I think that actually handicapped people, people with high -- high home-work burden, like women with small children, they actually are much freer to act in the new technology world actively on the job market.

So good things are happening, and they're happening also to people with limited education and skills. For example, channeling YouTube may make quite good money, and it doesn't take a degree at all.

So new jobs are coming. I don't know where, but the important thing is that we should actually support this change, not try to hold it back. I'm quite sure that in 15 years' time, in industry, all the things we need will be made with the same proportional workforce, which is currently in agriculture, 3 to 4 percent of all workforce, not more. The rest will work elsewhere, and they will do something online. What exactly, who knows?

Some things we can see already, but I'm sure there will be much more new stuff emerging, which we cannot imagine right now. At least, I cannot. I have a, well, not very good imagination.

SCIUTTO: Madam President, thank you very much. Just a phenomenal discussion.

(APPLAUSE)

END

ESTONIAN PRESIDENT KERSTI KALJULAID DELIVERS REMARKS ON CYBER-SECURITY AT AN ATLANTIC COUNCIL FORUM

APRIL 4, 2018

SPEAKERS: ESTONIAN PRESIDENT KERSTI KALJULAID

JIM SCIUTTO, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT

BARRY PAVEL, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, ARNOLD KANTER CHAIR, AND DIRECTOR, SCOWCROFT CENTER FOR STRATEGY AND SECURITY, ATLANTIC COUNCIL

DAVID LASHWAY, GLOBAL CO-CHAIR CYBERSECURITY, BAKER & MCKENZIE

[*] LASHWAY: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. I'm David Lashway, and I lead Baker McKenzie's cyber-security global practice. Delighted to have you all with us today.
